conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position and angle of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves forward, it changes the angle at which the light rays hit the objects.
Moving the light source forward typically means that the light rays become more perpendicular to the objects.

As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays are now coming from a position that is more directly above, reducing the horizontal distance the shadow is cast.
The size of the shadows will generally decrease as the light source moves forward because the light rays are more vertical, resulting in a smaller projection of the object's shape on the ground.
Shadow A (kimono) will shift closer to the kimono and become smaller.
Shadow B (postcard) will shift closer to the postcard and become smaller.
Shadow C (kimono's extended part) will shift closer to the extended part of the kimono and become smaller.
Shadow D (bottle) will shift closer to the bottle and become smaller.
